Sasha gave this amazing talk on our language model inversion research!

1. text embedding inversion (
arxiv.org/abs/2310.06816

)
2. language model output inversion (coming soon...)

citation: 
figure is from Text Embeddings Reveal (Almost) As Much As Text [
arxiv.org/abs/2310.06816

Vector databases have raised billions offering hosted management of text embeddings. What are you revealing in these vectors ? 🔒

We demonstrate a practical method for full recovery of 90% of sentence length embeddings (
arxiv.org/abs/2310.06816
Yes. Text embedding can recover the original text (
arxiv.org/abs/2310.06816
). While CLIP is still struggling with object counting and spatial reasoning, making it difficult to apply in manipulation, particularly in a zero-shot manner.
This carries big implications for intellectual property and national security (for LLMs trained on classified data).

Extract source text from embeddings & vectorDBs! 🌶️

"Text Embeddings Reveal (Almost) As Much As Text"

paper:
arxiv.org/abs/2310.06816
code:
github.com/jxmorris12/vec…
"a multi-step method that iteratively corrects and re-embeds text is able to recover 92% of 32-token text inputs…
Our work expands Vec2Text (Morris et al., 2023) (
arxiv.org/pdf/2310.06816…
) with extensive multilingual and cross-lingual investigation on inversion attacks and defences effective for both monolingual and multilingual embeddings.

a tiny summary of my research projects of 2023:

💽 Text Embeddings Reveal (Almost) As Much As Text
       EMNLP 2023,
arxiv.org/abs/2310.06816

🗣️ Language Model Inversion
       ICLR 2024,
arxiv.org/abs/2311.13647

🌲 TreePrompting
       EMNLP 2023,
arxiv.org/abs/2310.14034

haven't posted anything about (2) yet but here's the TLDR:

• given LM output probabilities, we can infer what the input prompt was
• we built a model that can do this
• most APIs don't give you probabilities, but we came up with a clever algorithm to get them using logit bias
more on this second paper soon but the paper draft is here
openreview.net/forum?id=t9dWH…

(hopefully w/ a new version on arxiv later this week)

and all the code for both papers is available in vec2text:
github.com/jxmorris12/vec…
x.com/canalCCore2/st…

Is it tho? These types of papers all expect the logits or probabilities to be available at a token level, but black box LLMs don’t provide that to my knowledge. It’s a really cool technique tho but I doubt how you would use it as a black box attack
It’s been studied for years (links below) though the point of my tweet (X?) was that this line of research showing promise is a big deal for the two areas.
usenix.org/system/files/s…
arxiv.org/pdf/2302.04237…
Thinking the same thing. What's the text-embedding equivalent model for vision? Does it have to be grounded by language?
Like CLIP but with more dynamic embedding with zooming in the region of interest?
DINO, LPIPS among others are image embedding models trained apart from language
Yes, but it then requires other fine-tuning techniques to extract the learned semantics.

The approach trains an inversion model on sentence embeddings, and applies vec2text, an iterative method for controllable editing to get closer to a ground-truth embedding. 

Code release includes Vec2text and models for OpenAI embeddings:
github.com/jxmorris12/vec…

We consider applying the method across textual domains (including medical data), test out various embedding models, and consider potential defenses. 

At least for short documents, our conclusion is that you should treat embeddings as uncompressed text.
Full paper, "Text Embeddings Reveal (Almost) As Much As Text" at EMNLP this year. Joint work with Jack Morris, Volodymyr Kuyleshov, and Vitaly Shmatikov at Cornell Tech
arxiv.org/abs/2310.06816

Interesting! I've done experiments on this task coming from the perspective of arithmetic coding (by iteratively "removing" representations from the embedding), but it required constraints on the generating process. Looking forward to digging into this paper.

Nice, we thought about a more information theoretic approach, but end up with a more brute force method. A couple years ago we wrote a paper on "Neural Linguistic Steganography" that sounds related to your approach
Am I right in thinking that this is very similar as a decoder in the pre-transformer era (RNNs), where one contextualized vector of the encoder was fed into the decoder as the first hidden state?
That's a good description of the task. The key distinction being that we don't have the ability to change (or get gradients from) the "encoder", which makes training harder.

Very interesting work - I wonder if this can be extended to visual data.

I remember seeing work on adversarial images a long time ago (~6-7 years), but that was more about generating a mislabeled image by perturbing a correctly labeled image with noise.
Yeah, I think folks have done this for vision. It's easier in a way because you can use gradient based search, where in text you need to be discrete

If I  create embeddings using OpenAI. So I can extract the actual text from it? 
If this is what is happening then  this will be really huge!
Yup:
github.com/jxmorris12/vec…

corrector = vec2text.load_corrector("text-embedding-ada-002")
vec2text.invert_embeddings(
    embeddings=embeddings.cuda(),
    corrector=corrector
)

vec2text was the original o1

1 LLM forward passes gets you back 30% of the text
50 LLM forward passes gets you back 90% of the text

just saying
interesting finding, I've noticed similar results in my own experiments with vec2text, seems like the key is finding that sweet spot between passes and accuracy

```

write me a poem about pizza
looks like someone's playing text hide and seek with extra steps 🤔
fractalicious , 88.9% is a boundary
lol

Would it make sense that if you made a model with a large encoder and a small decoder you can enforce a slow mode of thinking, reintegrating the entire message every time step, and a fast thinking mode using only the decoder model after a prompt?
Yeah you should sue
i am neither saying nor not saying that o1 is just vec2text++

Excited that my NLP security paper with

entities.name: Johannes Bjerva
entities.text: @johannesbjerva

entities.name: Heather Lent
entities.text: @heather_nlp
, entitled, Text Embedding Inversion Security for Multilingual Language Models (
arxiv.org/abs/2401.12192
), has been accepted to ACL 2024 main conference track 🤗

This paper is the first to investigate multilingual textual embedding inversion attacks, shedding light on the differences in attacks and defenses across monolingual and multilingual settings. Our code and models are open-sourced
github.com/siebeniris/Mul…

We show that the multilingual embeddings trained on texts in multiple languages can be more vulnerable than their monolingual counterparts, especially for base models, such as for French, German and Spanish.

With qualitative analysis in inverting English and German texts, we can see that some embeddings can be inverted into the exact original texts after just 6-7 steps of converging the hypotheses and original embeddings with cosine similarity in the embedding space.

To investigate cross-lingual inversion attack, we use inversion model trained on multilingual embeddings in one source language (e.g. German) to invert texts in other target languages (e.g. English), it is interesting that the inverted texts in this scenario are only in source…

language.  In this case the usual evaluation metrics such as BLEU would not capture the security breaches, so we introduced AdTrans to translate the target language texts into source language texts. The results are massively improved.

To fully preserve the utility of embeddings while make them more secure, we investigate the defense mechanisms with retrieval tasks. The proposed noise insertion defense mechanism only works for monolingual embeddings while ineffective for multilingual embeddings. We propose …
We propose a simple masking mechanism, that is effective for both monolingual and multilingual embeddings.

In Conclusion, we’ve unveiled the first study on multilingual & cross-lingual embedding inversion attacks. 🔑Key findings: Multilingual models can be more vulnerable than monolingual ones, and traditional defenses fall short. Our proposed solution strengthens both types. Plus, ..
we stress the need to expand research to include diverse languages. Multilingual security is crucial for Security & NLP! 🌐🔍
#AI
#NLP

#Cybersecurity

#LLMSec
#MultilingualAI

Similar concern wrt watermarking as well

I’m familiar with the first paper! Matthew was a speaker in my class. My understanding is that the team hasn’t been able to replicate this with MoE type models, or generally black box models with input/output filters. Not familiar with the second one. Thanks for sharing
I see. I wonder if the image embedding of SAM can be an alternative. It can give high res segmentation mask from the embedding, so the embedding must be keeping that level of spatial information.
I’m not sure I understand then, what is the desired behavior?
Probably yes, but not sure about the "reasoning" part. For example, to prompt with "the furthest object from the object A", or "the object with the closest size of object A".
I was thinking if given a really good image embedding model which contains all fine-grained pixel-level semantics, would it be possible to directly solve the reposted V*Bench.

Congratulations! 🎉

Really cool work, I once attended a talk at MIT on private information retrieval and left thinking surely there was something to it — I can imagine maybe a centralized vector index of medical info and queries from hospitals that can’t be vec2text-ed and…
That's really interesting. Would be curious who the speaker was if you remember.
Very cool! Could this be used to translate between different embedding models, OpenAI <-> all-MiniLM-L6-v2 <-> Cohere?
That's a fun idea. My guess is that  you could do that by directly learning a mapping. But this method could perhaps make it provably correct.

Super cool - and same as encryption, I imagine it gets weaker if you can feed the inversion model more context about the sentence itself.

What would be the best stage to inject textual context (other de-embedded sentences, keywords, etc) into the model?

It's a good question, we don't try anything specifically like this, but you could certainly fine-tune in domain. You could also apply other controlled generation techniques like A* or neurologic to reduce the search space with this side information.

very interesting!

have you probed for a text-token-length at which the recovery quality falls off sharply, which seems necessary on info-theoretic grounds? (similarly: are such failures still reasonable summaries of the longer text?) …

Great work. Privacy in vector databases is more important than ever.

This is not a database security issue. This shows that embeddings can be converted back to text. In Pinecone, data (including embeddings) is encrypted, so this makes no difference.
Got it, that makes sense. Because the embeddings are encrypted, then one won't be able to convert them back to text.

…
eg: with dims as 4-byte floats, a 1536d embedding from `text-embedding-ada-002` uses ~49,000 bits (!).

using a classic estimate of an English word-token's info as ~11.8 bits, a 32-token text should be representable in ~378 bits. …

…
so, the embedding (or just its sign bits!) plenty *spacious* for encoding (by design or emergently) a 32-word compressed representation, even if not engineered as rigorous lossless compression.

it'd be neat to characterize ranges over which this works, & where/how it decays.
So an attacker might try all the commonly used APIs.

Yup, this is a great point. Even quantized embeddings have a surprisingly large amount of storage. 

We do see drop off at larger lengths, however we think this may be for practical reasons. Would be nice to know the limit here. (We tried a bit, but didn't find anything clean).

Amazing work but I'm curious why the jailbreak prompts performed low on instruction 2M, were they new jailbreak prompts or the older ones?
We found they worked well on regular models, but not as well on Chat. I think it was best of a collection of 10 prompts that should be in the appendix (if not we will add them).
